key_points: Winter Storm Uri brought extreme cold across the United States, impacting states like Texas with unusual severe weather.
The cold snap caused massive energy demand spikes and blackouts, leaving millions without power.
Scientists are divided on whether climate change is increasing the likelihood of such extreme cold events.
Some researchers argue global warming could make these events less likely, while others suggest warming in the Arctic could lead to more frequent cold spells further south.
Walt Meier, a senior research scientist, describes the phenomenon as controversial among scientists.
Factors like sudden stratospheric warming and variations in the Arctic Oscillation contributed to the recent cold weather.
The Arctic is warming twice as fast as the rest of the planet, a phenomenon with uncertain implications for extreme weather patterns.
Jennifer Francis notes that the current cold event aligns with predictions that such extreme weather will become more common in a warming climate.
Francis points out that extreme heat and cold can co-exist due to the meandering jet stream.
James Screen expresses skepticism over a direct link between climate change and increased extreme cold events.
spokespersons: Walt Meier (Senior Research Scientist, National Snow and Ice Data Center at the University of Colorado Boulder)
Karin Gleason (Climate Scientist, National Centers for Environmental Information at NOAA)
Jennifer Francis (Senior Scientist, Woodwell Climate Research Center)
James Screen (Associate Professor of Climate Science, University of Exeter)
